more about this stuff as i like to do so let's get started about what i mean
about event based computing or event-based automation so
when you are developing products when you're running products in production there are a lot of things going on and a
lot of this stuff is as event-based so examples of this could be for example that
you're sending a message to a message queue you need to respond to that but i'm also referring to events such as
a new container image version is being pushed maybe someone pushes a commit to github
or a pull request is approved so these are all events in the ecosystem around uh your software
development process really and uh in many of these cases you need to respond to this
in various ways uh preferably using some kind of automation so examples of this could be that you
typically want to trigger a build perhaps when a new commit is pushed uh maybe you want to
create or tear down a testing environment to run some smoke
tests for example perhaps you need to do security scans on a container image
another example could also be that you want to you need to scale your application up and down
depending on the load of the application so if you're receiving a lot of messages you might need to respond to that by
scaling up and down and of course there are many other things that you could need to do here
and the topic of this talk is to show you how you can realize this using kubernetes and kind
of driving the point that if you are running kubernetes you have this huge platform
which you can use for not just running your application in production but also to implement this kind of automation
that goes on around the application or your systems and of course if you have been using you
know kubernetes and working around the cloud native stuff uh there's a huge
ecosystem around this there are so many tooling available in that implements all aspects um that you
can use here and i'll be focusing on two different products that we are using
and the first one is called brigade which is uh event-driven scripting for kubernetes
and the other one is called the cada which is kubernetes-based event-driven auto-scaling
both of these products are open source uh and active um and uh i'll be showing you demos
for both these projects and they are targeting a little bit the different scenarios of course but
they're both related to implementing event driven
automation so i'll start with talking about brigade um this is the brigade is an open source
project from the guys that also built uh for example helm and draft and
the main point of brigade is to change together containers to create
workflows in your in your kubernetes cluster so the idea here is that you have all this
functionality available at container images this might be public container images or they might be
your own container images that you build yourself so the idea is that you don't have to
you know rebuild this functionality instead you just need some way to to use these images and to chain them
together to create you know either simple or or complex workflows inside your existing kubernetes cluster
and brigade doesn't really require anything extra you just installed into your cluster and
you're good to go you don't need anything extra and so this will run in any kubernetes cluster either
on-premise or or in any of the cloud providers out there brigade uses javascript to
create the pipelines so so the pipelines that's how you're chaining uh your containers together so this is a
super simple example of how you're creating what's called a job and i'll go more into the details later
on here but basically you're creating a job specifying the your container images and then you're telling it
what tasks should be run inside this image and you can run them serially you can run them in parallel and so on so
you have a lot of options but the idea is that you're using javascript to to implement this pipeline
and you can store this code you know together with the rest of the application or you can store it separately
it really depends on the scenario here and of course there will be a lot of
integration going on here and brigade comes with the ready-made integrations
for example to integrate with github to respond to any kind of events that goes on in your github repository
also services such as azure event grid azure container registry and also kubernetes itself
and and many more here so these are ready-made integrations that are available so you
don't really have to understand uh the format of this or the apis here
but in addition to this there's also what's called a generic gateway which really allows you to
to integrate with with any kind of api as long as you can speak json over http uh you're really good to
go so let's uh take a look at the the architecture of brigade
uh so that has this concept of a gateway and the gateway is which will you'll be
triggering with some kind of vent from the outside so for example this could be
this could be a trigger from the outside of example somebody is you know pushing
a commit to to github and now the gateway will
will respond to this by looking up the product so a product in brigade is uh
for every type of automation you will you're creating a project implicated that contains some metadata around this project and
so depending on the on the trigger coming in the gate will accept the the product to know what should happen
the uh to handle this this uh this web hook that comes in from the outside
so the gateway will then translate this into an event and will kick off a build inside your kubernetes cluster
and inside this build it will be running then one or more jobs depending on how your javascript
pipeline looks like so you can run them again you can run them sequentially you can run them in parallel so you can really
create simple or complex workflows here

and so the second part i'm going to talk about the product called cada so again this is
also related to events but this is related to scaling uh which is a very common thing to do uh
when you get a lot of events if you have event driven applications based on on you know queues or service buses and you start to
get a lot of events sorry a lot of messages you need to to scale your application up and down
so circada is an open source component for event driven scaling in kubernetes and
it allows you to scale from from zero up to thousands you know or
how many instances of your applications that your cluster allows you to run and the
zero part here is actually a bit interesting because as i will mention later on also um
kubernetes has already auto scaling built in but uh it can scale from zero you need
to have at least one instance running before it can scale it whilst keda actually allows you to scale
from no instances which is actually a very interesting in in various cases
but also cada doesn't replace the kubernetes auto scaling it actually uses it um because the main
point here is that for the the kubernetes auto scaling is built
it uses a metric such as cpu and memory consumptions which works
fine for some types of application to scale so if you have a lot of load on your web app you can scale it out
but if you're looking at country of an applications where you have things like service buses or message queues
and you start getting a lot of messages on that message queue that doesn't really cause your application to you know to
consume a lot of cpu it will just continue to to pull that that cue you know one message at a time
and you'll be building up a huge huge queue there um so
what you need what you want to do here is that if you see that you have a lot a huge message queue lying there you want
to make sure that you can scale up your application to consume those message faster and this is exactly what what cada allows you to do
and it supports a lot of various event sources like the the azure event sources
the the search bus or or the storage queues but also a lot of other ones like the aws or kafka or rabbit mq and
so on also what what cada allows you to do is you can run
and scale your azure functions in kubernetes so azure functions is of course a pass
service that allows you to very easily implement small functionality small integrations
and just run them in in azure and azure can also then it will
instantiate and also scale them appropriately when you are starting to get loads so that's a
function is a great runtime it's a great programming environment to implement this in but there are actually cases when you might want to
to use to use them but actually run them in in kubernetes because that allows you to for example
run things on premise or behind firewalls um and and a few other scenarios
so microsoft has the whole azure function runtime is
available as a docker image from microsoft that you can use and so you can just package your application inside the docker image
and then deploy it into kubernetes now the the big thing you're missing
when you do that is that how how would you scale it if you're running azure functions
in in pass you'll you'll get scaling automatically but if you're running kubernetes you
don't really have anything to scale it for you so this is what cada brings to the table so it will actually help you to
deploy your azure functions into kubernetes and scale it based on various event sources
again so i'll show you them on both these things
so again uh keda doesn't uh you know replace the horizontal pod auto scaler
which is the scaling component of kubernetes it adds on top of it and it supports a lot
of various event sources and have scalars for them so a scalar is is the component that actually
will monitor a particular event source and scale your application up and down so
you can see that the list of event sources is long and it's it keeps growing
and the kayla product actually reached ga 1.0 well now it's uh i think it's four or
five months ago so so it's it's a healthy uh and uh thriving project in in the open source world
so if you have been working with humanities you might know about the horizontal pod auto scaler which is a component you install and you
configure it to scale your deployment for example based on on the cpu so you
can say things like if my if my pods consume more than 80 cpu
i want you to to scale up to to a particular amount of pods so i can hand that load better but again
this doesn't really work for very well for for event driven applications so let's take a look at
scala scaling uh so a typical criteria that you have a deployment with a pod
and then you have some kind of queue somewhere that you you you are monitoring so you're sending and you're receiving messages
from that queue so what you do then is that you
configure your installing cada into your cluster and you configure it to use a scalar for
that particular type of queue and that scalar then contains something called the scaled object
that's the definition really of which cube to monitor and how to scale your deployment i will show you the details uh right up
after this so you configure to to monitor the queue
and based on on the metrics for that queue typically the message links how many
messages are currently on that queue it will then configure the horizontal pod auto scaler
appropriately and they will then scale my my deployment up and down which
then allows me to to consume messages from that queue
faster until the queue is empty and then i can scale down again
so the scaled object looks like this this is a custom resource definition crd in in kubernetes which is a way to
extend kubernetes and there are a few main parts here um
first of all we have the scale target draft that this is where you specify which deployment do i want to scale
using this so in this case i have a deployment called order processor which is the component that actually
receives and processes messages from the queue so that's the one i want to scale up if i see that i have a lot of messages
coming in because that allows me to consume them faster
the other one is the trigger part and depending on the type of event source that you're using this this
is going to look a little bit different in this case i configured to use the azure service bus
and then i specify the name of the queue and i give it the connection string and i'm specifying the queue length to be
five so that means that if the number of messages reaches above five that's the signal
then for for cada to say that now i'll actually i want to scale up my deployment
because i'm getting a lot of messages and i want to make sure that i consume them you know within a certain amount of time
so i want to scale up and the last part here is where you can figure how that scaling should
the boundaries for that scaling so in this case i'm saying that i
i want to always have at least one pod one replica running and i want you to scale up to 10 to the
maximum of 10 replicas so this is depending on you know the your cluster how much resources you have
available and so on and then you have polling interval which is how often should the
should the cada scaler check the the queue in this case so every fifth second and
